sub_title: Postdoc Freshwater Biodiversity at IGB Berlin
summary:
My passion for fish ecology, biodiversity and nature conservation runs like a thread through my academic career. Communication, dedication, perseverance, and patience are all key parts of my work. My strengths are in conducting fundamental research, communicating with scientists and volunteers from various research fields, and providing constructive solutions by balancing the interests of various stakeholders. I'm always looking for new ways to get people and organisations to collaborate effectively in order to promote conservation. I believe that transboundary cooperation is essential for effective conservation of freshwater biodiversity and that this should be facilitated as much as possible through science.

Visit my personal website http://twanstoffers.com

education.field_of_study: Biology, Human and Animal Health Biology

awards.title: WIAS Publication prize 2021
awards.description: Publication prize awarded by the Wageningen Institute of Animal Sciences (Wageningen University) based on: the originality of the research, the quality of the scientific analysis, the quality of the written presentation and the impact of the publication

awards.title: WUR In The Spotlight prize
awards.description: Twan Stoffers (AFI) is selected by the jury and the directors of WUR Animal Sciences Group for a place IN THE SPOTLIGHT in the category Publication. Twan is rewarded for his publication in ‘Science of the total environment’ on the effects of ecological restoration projects. It was his first publication. In addition to a publication in a high impact journal, Twan's research has also received due attention in the popular media.

awards.title: GCFI Travel award 2019
awards.description: PhD Student Travel Award is to encourage and help PhD candidates in their work in Caribbean ecology and fisheries and showcase their ideas and work in an oral presentation.

projects.title: Save Our Sharks
projects.description:
I am involved in the Save Our Sharks project (DCNA) in the Dutch Caribbean as fieldwork and software trainer in video analysis of shark populations.

Working with fishermen, scientists and local communities, we will put an end to the slaughter of sharks in the Dutch Caribbean and encourage islanders to benefit from their presence as a valuable tourism asset. By 2017 sharks will flourish in our waters, protected by islanders and valued both as integral part of our marine heritage and as a valuable tourism asset.

By the end of this project there will be:
• Substantial popular support for shark conservation
• Complete ban on commercial and targeted fishing for sharks
• Established sanctuaries as safe havens for sharks

contributors.headline: Postdoc Freshwater Biodiversity at IGB Berlin

projects.title: MSc. Biology thesis on fish ecomorphology on the Saba bank (Dutch Caribbean)
projects.description:
The effect of habitat type on the morphological diversity of reef fish assemblages of the Saba bank: combining stereo video assessments with the Fish Food Model (FFM)

The aims of this research are:
1.	Determining the fish community structure on different locations on the Saba bank with BRUV. For each species the relative abundance (MaxN) and fish length is measured and species richness is related to different sampling areas. Sampling areas are categorized in habitat types using a 6-point scale (A-F) to relate species richness to habitat type.
2.	For the top 15 fish species (families) occurring on the Saba bank, some of the 35 ecomorphological traits are obtained by dissection. With FFM (Sibbing and Nagelkerke, 2001) the species are classified in trophic groups according to morphological traits, based on their feeding strategies. The composition of trophic groups is analyzed per habitat type and differences are related between habitat types and fishing pressure.
3.	Fish community structures (trophic groups) on the Saba bank are obtained in areas with and without fisheries activity. In this way effect of fisheries on fish community structures (trophic groups) are analyzed. When present, further analysis of the data is done to establish the extent of the influence of fisheries on the community structures.

projects.title: MSc. Biology thesis on eye movement in lifebearing fish
projects.description:
Abstract of my report:
This study aims on establishing if learning plays a role the development of preying skills in newborns of the viviparous fish Girardinus metallicus. Feeding experiments were done to study the ontogeny of eye movement (eye version and vergence) and speed of approach in relation to successful prey capture events in newborn fish. The relation between these parameters and the development of the probability of successful prey capture was used to describe the change in preying skills over time. From an evolutionary perspective, development of these parameters should result in a decreased probability of unsuccessful prey capture events. Changes in preying skills can roughly be explained by learning processes (experience) and maturation of the body (age of fish). In order to distinguish between those two processes, the parameters are analyzed both in time (age of fish) and experience (successive number of prey capture events). The probability of unsuccessful prey capture events declined with both age and experience. Decreasing eye vergence and version angles and increasing speed of approach levels were found in newborn viviparous fish during development. The change is eye movement parameters could indicate a process of automating the eye-body coordination, which is a learned behavior. Newborn fish rely mainly on visual feedback during their prey capture events, while older fish use less visual feedback and rely more on their experience. The increasing average speed levels in time could be explained by the development of more muscle tissue (maturation of the body) and better control over motor activities due to developmental programs in the brain and continuous sensory feedback. The influences of other parameters on prey capture events in newborns of Girardinus metallicus are still unknown and can only partly be extracted from the dataset of this study.

projects.title: BSc. Biology thesis on Coral Bleaching
projects.description: An extensive literature study on the causes and trends of coral bleaching. Coral bleaching is a process in which corals expel their symbiotic zooxanthellae partners due to environmental stress factors. Both bleaching events and global temperature have increased the last decades and there has been increasingly more evidence that elevated seawater temperature directly cause coral bleaching, but there is not always a significant correlation. Other factors that cause stress in corals may contribute to the outbreak of local and worldwide bleaching events, such as: pathogenic infections; decreased salinity; exposure to low tides; sedimentation; increase in solar radiation; cyanide fishing; increase in atmospheric CO2 concentrations and a combination of these factors.

company.name: Leibniz Institute of Freshwater Ecology and Inland Fisheries (IGB)

profile_positions.company: Leibniz Institute of Freshwater Ecology and Inland Fisheries (IGB)
profile_positions.description: In this role I lead the freshwater case-study within the BioAgora project, a five-year EU-funded project aiming to support sustainable transformation for biodiversity in Europe. BioAgora will develop the architecture and functionality of the new European “Science Service for Biodiversity” that will fully support the ecological transition required by the European Green Deal and the EU’s Biodiversity Strategy for 2030.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher Freshwater Biodiversity

profile_positions.description: I am involved in the protection of Caribbean shark populations as expert for the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality in a Caribbean-wide working group of scientists and conservationists (SPAW). In this role I help to implement the protocol concerning Specially Protected Areas and Wildlife in the Caribbean region (SPAW-RAC). This includes: proposal writing and evaluating, consultation and attending the meetings of the Scientific and Technical Advisory Committee (SPAW-STAC)
profile_positions.title: Independent expert in species working group

profile_positions.description: In this role I was in charge of managing and coordinating fieldwork activities, data collection and analysis, report/paper writing, and educational activities. In this large-scale project, I investigated how restored floodplains in the Netherlands function as nursery areas for riverine fishes. I worked on projects ranging from assessing the ecological efficacy of restored floodplains over time to assessing food availability and gut contents of juvenile fish, as well as extensive habitat modelling.
profile_positions.title: PhD Candidate Fish Ecology

profile_positions.description: I analysed standardised video surveys in the Dutch Caribbean (Bonaire, St. Eustatius, Saba, St. Maarten) to study fish community dynamics and shark abundances. I also provided regular on-site field training for staff and students of local conservation organisations.
profile_positions.title: Fish Community Analysis Specialist

profile_positions.description:
- BRUV (Baited Remote Underwater Video) and DOV (Diver Operated Video) fieldwork and data analysis training.
- Fish community research: video analysis of diving surveys of the coastline of Bonaire (Dutch Caribbean). Videos are analyzed with EventMeasure (SeaGIS) software, specially designed for underwater video surveys.
profile_positions.title: Data analyst tropical fish communities

profile_positions.description: Baited Remote Underwater Video (BRUV) survey was used to detect changes in reef fish assemblage structures on the Saba bank (Netherlands Caribbean). Between 2012-2014, a total of 165 fish assemblages were assessed with BRUVs on locations varying in habitat complexity level, depth layer and fisheries activity. The study identified 135 fish species belonging to 39 families, with Labridae as most abundant family. Clear differences in reef fish assemblages were found for species richness (Nsp), fish abundance (MaxN), mean biomass and trophic level.
profile_positions.title: MSc Marine Biology Researcher Saba Bank

profile_positions.description:
As project officer I was responsible for the implementation of the shark conservation project “Save our Sharks” on six Caribbean islands. I successfully wrote a grant proposal for a Caribbean bat conservation project within the EU BEST2.0 programme, and I was involved in other aspects of conservation management and education in the Dutch Caribbean. My work included: daily project management
activities, co-ordination of science, assisting in fieldwork activities, on-island assistance, development of education materials, event management and project liaison.
profile_positions.title: Project Officer 'Save Our Sharks'

profile_positions.description: I educated students (further education) on the basics of working in a biological laboratory. Work includes: experiments with DNA isolation, bacterial growth, medical analysis, and chemistry/physics.
profile_positions.title: Biology laboratory Teacher

profile_positions.description: Preparing breakfast, lunch, and dinner dishes. Fully functional cook, trained in preparing a la carte buffet form of cooking. Key words: Leadership, Stress management, Time management, Food preparation and presentation, Teamwork and team management, Assertive, Creative and progressive
profile_positions.title: Executive Chef

volunteer_experiences.description: Installation, security checks and maintenance (including cleaning) of moorings for yachts and dive boats, to prevent anchoring on the delicate sea bottom substrate.
Training of girl soccer team and kitchen activities
Helping the SCF with their weekly snorkel club activities. This includes: learning kids how the swim, teaching them about marine life and giving them a fun time!
